citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care.
citations.narrative:
During the September 2024 Semiannual facility inspection, it was reported that a bat was present in an isolation cage
used for injured animals, however, the Department of Lab Animal Medicine (DLAM) veterinarians were not contacted
about this injured animal. The discovery was made by one of the clinical veterinarians who immediately assessed the bat
and determined a minor injury with no negative impact on its welfare. The study area management (SAM) document for
bat husbandry states that any bats appearing sick, injured, or ill will be reported to the DLAM veterinary health service. On
this occasion, there was no report or communication to the appropriate veterinary staff. Failure to report an animal injury
to the DLAM in a timely manner can result in delayed treatment, resulting in unnecessary pain and distress, or possible
death. Each research facility shall establish and maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that include daily
observation of all animals to assess their health and well-being; Provided, however, That daily observation of animals may
be accomplished by someone other than the attending veterinarian; and Provided, further, That a mechanism of direct
and frequent communication is required so that timely and accurate information on problems of animal health, behavior,
and well-being is conveyed to the attending veterinarian.
Corrected on 9/11/2024

The following sanitation issues were noted in the room adjacent to the anteroom in the building where fruit bats are
housed: The sink and counters had a moderate amount of dust and debris present. Additionally, there were cobwebs
accumulating insects and debris located above the sink. The sponge and cleaning brushes appeared unclean and were
being stored directly in the sink and on top of a soiled countertop. Under the sink was a dismantled, rusted metal shelf
and a small, travel kennel with a mild amount of dust. The floors appeared soiled and there was an accumulation of debris
concentrated in the corners of the room. PPE supplies to enter the bat enclosure are stored on a shelf in this area and
may become easily contaminated. Failure to clean and sanitize animal areas as required may increase the potential for
disease hazards to animal housing areas. Premises (buildings and grounds) shall be kept clean and in good repair in
order to protect the animals from injury and to facilitate the prescribed husbandry practices set forth in this subpart.
Accumulations of trash shall be placed in designated areas and cleared as necessary to protect the health of the animals.
To be corrected by 7/18/2025
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representatives.
